context: The presence of methanotrophs suggest that aerobic biodegradation by cometabolism of TCE with methane may also occur. These data suggest two possible mechanisms for natural attenuation of TCE by anaerobic biodegradation of the highly chlorinated compounds may predominate in the plume and aerobic biodegradation may occur in oxygenated zones (e.g. seep, near the water table, and in fracture zones which receives periodic flushes of oxygenated storm water). These processes may result in nearly complete biodegradation of the TCE and its daughter products and may be the first field study to observe natural attenuation of TCE in fractured shale bedrock. This study combined VOC and redox potential data, with enrichment and molecular techniques, to examine natural attenuation at a hydrogeologically complex site. If one of the techniques was used, an incomplete view of natural attenuation at the site would result. With coupled geochemical–microbial analyses, it is possible to develop a more reliable conceptual model of natural attenuation.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,1,2-trichloroethene (TCE) is discussed in relation to natural attenuation processes, which include both anaerobic and aerobic biodegradation mechanisms. The presence of methanotrophs indicates that aerobic biodegradation may contribute to the attenuation of TCE in oxygenated zones. The study highlights the importance of understanding these natural attenuation processes in the context of TCE contamination in fractured shale bedrock, suggesting a significant relationship between TCE and its attenuation mechanisms.

The evidence provided supports the relationship, indicating that both anaerobic and aerobic mechanisms play a role in TCE degradation.
